docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from an interview with President Clinton conducted on July 8 with reporters and editors of The New York Times: Q. If you look across the four years of your Administration, your first two years were your most activist ones, probably the ones where you had the most accomplishments. And yet, that was when your popularity was lowest and the public voted in the Republicans in Congress. The last two years, the Republicans have been in control of Congress, and yet your popularity has soared. What do you make of this strange situation?

docs.lead_paragraph: SINGLE parents and two-income families alike face the dilemma every day: Who takes care of the children while the adults are at work? Traditionally their choices have been limited to day care centers, babysitters and nannies. But 10 years ago another attractive option became available: a Federally approved program that supplies European au pairs to American families. The first such program, Au Pair in America, a Greenwich-based operation, has brought more than 70,000 young Europeans to the United States, this year placing 4,000 au pairs with families in 36 states, including 408 in Connecticut.

headline.main: Help From Overseas in Raising Youngsters

docs.lead_paragraph: Barbara Jo Dollinger, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Les Dollinger of Hillsboro, Ill., was married yesterday to Joseph N. Walsh 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walsh Jr. of Bedford, N.Y. Msgr. Charles Swiger performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Church in Bedford. Mrs. Walsh, 33, is a vice president in New York with Nomura Securities International, a stock brokerage firm. She graduated from the University of Iowa. Her father, now retired, was the Superintendent of Schools in Hillsboro, Ill.

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Gov. George E. Pataki introduced his bare-bones budget proposal for 1996-97 back in December, state legislators pulled in their belts an extra notch and prepared for the worst. By July 13, however, about $1.4 billion in proposed cuts were restored, and a $66 billion spending package was approved for the state -- which made taxpayers, school administrators, hospital officials, environmentalists and other constituent groups very happy indeed.

headline.main: Pros and Cons of a Late Budget

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR the thousands of New York State businesses that pay a total of $5 billion for workers' compensation insurance each year, the significance of recently approved legislation revamping the system should be as clear as the numbers on their premium bills: it will help reduce rates by as much as 25 percent, state officials say. But for the workers who depend on the system to provide medical care for work-related injuries and compensation for lost wages, the impact of the new measure will be less clear, and probably less consequential. It will neither increase their benefits, as the bill's authors once promised, nor cause the dire consequences its critics had predicted.

headline.main: Albany Bill Expands Managed Care in Worker Injuries

docs.lead_paragraph: Joan Melissa McNichol, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James B. McNichol Jr. of Edison, N.J., was married on Thursday to Ray Anthony Nieves, a son of Clifford Nieves of Tampa, Fla., and the late Amparo Nieves. The Rev. Peter Padro, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Manor, a restaurant in West Orange, N.J. Mrs. McNichol-Nieves, 39, is the coordinator of the substance awareness program for the Harrison, N.J., public schools. She graduated magna cum laude from Kean College of New Jersey, where she also received a master's degree in educational psychology and a certificate in counseling in business and industry. Her father, who is retired, owned J & J Accounting in Iselin, N.J.

docs.lead_paragraph: His hands in restless motion, Bill Clinton sat in the Oval Office earlier this month assessing the Presidency he calls "this great adventure." At times pensive, other times fiery, his finger stabbing the air as he disputed a point, he confidently made his case for a second term. "As Americans, what we have done in the last four years is put our economic house in order, restore growth and create opportunity," Mr. Clinton said. "We have succeeded in reducing the deficit, expanding trade, targeting investment in critical areas, and we have over 10 million new jobs."

headline.main: Despite His Reversals, Clinton Stays Centered

docs.lead_paragraph: WILLIAM KOSBOB says he rarely gets angry, really angry. That requires too much energy, he says. Thoughts of vengeance would only clog his mind, which must remain focused on keeping his family intact. His son Mathew, 16, has been hospitalized with severe and irreversible brain damage suffered in a beating in Stamford a year ago tonight. So much of Mathew's brain was destroyed by repeated blows to the head with a 40-ounce beer bottle that doctors do not expect him to live more than five to seven years, even with around-the-clock care.

docs.lead_paragraph: Congressional leaders have struck an acceptable, though troubling, compromise on medical savings accounts that should allow Congress to pass a useful health-care bill. President Clinton eagerly awaits the moment he can sign something, anything, that carries the mantle of health-care reform and thereby blunt the memory of the greatest legislative fiasco of his Administration. The House and Senate have passed bills that provide for "portability" -- a guarantee to workers who are dismissed or change jobs that they will be offered coverage regardless of their medical condition. The bills do not help the uninsured or guarantee dislocated workers policies they can afford. But they provide modest protection for millions of workers who fear they are too sick to find coverage.

docs.lead_paragraph: The German insurer Allianz A.G. agreed yesterday to sell DKV, Europe's largest private health insurer, to the world's largest reinsurer, Munich Re, allowing it to avoid a battle with regulators over its dominance in health insurance. Financial terms were not disclosed, but industry officials and analysts estimated the price was about 4 billion marks ($2.7 billion). Analysts expressed surprise that Allianz chose to sell DKV and hold onto its Vereinte Group, Germany's second-largest health insurer. The sale of DKV ends almost two years of speculation that Allianz would sell Vereinte, which it bought in 1994 from the Swiss reinsurer Swiss Re. Reinsurers take on insured risks from other insurance companies.

headline.main: Allianz Health Insurer To Be Sold to Munich Re
